prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for refusing to go to a surprise vacation paid for by my girlfriend?

Throwaway as I don’t want my girlfriend to see this post.

Just a bit of background info: my girlfriend works in HR and I work in IT for the same company, however because we work in two different branches we only really get to see each other before/after our shift as our lunch breaks are scheduled at different times. Important to note that we report to the same big boss even though we’re in different departments. Anyways, my birthday was two days ago. My girlfriend and I celebrated by going to a fancy restaurant and having a glass of wine after. Then she starts babbling about a “surprise” she has for me, and gives me an envelope. In the envelope are return flights to Switzerland, for a two-week holiday! Immediately I began to wonder how this holiday would work considering I hadn’t applied for leave, but before I could even ask, she said she talked to our boss months in advance and told him to keep it a secret. I didn’t say anything but I was really annoyed. Asking our boss for couples’ leave is just unprofessional and could jeopardize my career. Not only that, but she never asked me if I was okay with using my leave for an overseas holiday. I would much prefer using that time to relax and sleep. I was going to suggest her returning the tickets but she has already paid for everything, including ski resorts, and I figure she would incur various cancellation fees. I just believe that she should have asked me, because I do not want to travel overseas while on leave. I guess I didn’t act as enthused as she wanted me to because she asked me why I was unhappy, and I told her that I would refuse to go as she should have asked me first. She’s annoyed at me. My close friends are telling me that I’m being ungrateful and that I should just go. AITA?
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to work through this. The user is asking whether the author is in the wrong for refusing a surprise vacation arranged by his girlfriend. The author's main points are that the trip was planned without his input, the boss was involved in a way he considers unprofessional, and he prefers to use his leave for relaxation instead. 

First, the girlfriend paid for the trip, including flights and a resort. The author didn't like that she went to their mutual boss to get the leave without consulting him. He feels she should have asked first because using the vacation time for an overseas trip might be unprofessional, and he's not interested in traveling. His friends say he's ungrateful.

Hmm, so from the author's perspective, he's upset because his preferences weren't considered. He might feel his autonomy was disregarded. On the other hand, the girlfriend did plan a surprise, which is meant to be a nice gesture, and she went through the effort to arrange everything. She might feel hurt that he's rejecting it without being more appreciative.

Is the author in the wrong? Well, he did say he's not interested in the trip. But maybe he could have been more appreciative of the gesture, even if he declined. However, the key issue is that she arranged the trip without his consent, which is a big deal. He has the right to decide how to use his vacation time. The fact that she involved their boss might add to the unprofessionalism he's concerned about. So, while he might have a valid point about the lack of consultation, maybe he could have handled the refusal more gracefully. But ultimately, the main wrong here is her not asking him first. So he's not in the wrong for refusing, but perhaps his reaction could have been better. Wait, the question is whether he's in the wrong. If he's not the one who skipped the consultation, then he's not the one at fault. So answer B.
